body:
If we want unambiguity, can we follow the practice we use in cmdlets? I mean that if name resolution returns several results, then throw.

/cc @mklement0

@iSazonov 	That code is already there.  End the end, both code paths, use the same code.  I doubt anyone actually wants to do execution based on wildcards.  It can lead to executing unexpected files and VERY bad results.
Glad to see this is getting fixed; it addresses at least part of #4726, which also asks for the `>`, `>>` behavior to be fixed - will this PR address that too (haven't looked)?

@mklement0 	The intent was not to fix that issue.  As #4726 does not directly affect execution, I would not think that the issue would be considered a Defense in Depth fix and I'd prefer to get this fix in before addressing that issue.
Thanks for clarifying, @TravisEz13 (but note that #4726 is about execution _as well_).
@TravisEz13 Can you please summarize what is asked from the committee to review?

Committee ask:

Please review this breaking change.

Before this change, if a user attempted to run `.\[my1].ps1` and there is a `1.ps1` in the same folder, `1.ps1` would be executed instead because we performed globbing on executed commands.

It would fail if there were multiple files matching the statement and fall back to the literal path if no match was found.

After the change, execution always uses literal path.

The behavior was regressed in Windows Server 2016/Windows 10 Anniversary Edition/WMF 5.1 when a change to support the same type of patterns was added to `Get-Command` for relative command search.  There was no indication in the change description that the intent was to add this support for command execution execution as well.

@PowerShell/powershell-committee reviewed this, our proposal is to simply switch the behavior so that literal path is treated first and if not found, then attempt globbing.  We need to also fix the separate issue (outside of this PR) where the escaped literal path is not accepted: ./\`[my1\`].ps1

Related https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/5785

@TravisEz13, your last commit had 1 failures in `PowerShell-CI-windows`
Command Discovery tests.Use literal path first when executing scripts.'fully qualified path with bracket wildcard matctching one file' should not execute
```powershell
Expected an exception, with FullyQualifiedErrorId 'CommandNotFoundException' to be thrown, but no exception was thrown.
at <ScriptBlock>, D:\a\1\s\test\powershell\engine\Basic\CommandDiscovery.Tests.ps1: line 119
119:             { & $command } | Should -Throw -ErrorId 'CommandNotFoundException'
```

Should we document the command searcher process in Docs repo?
The command searcher itself is an implementation detail.  We should document the search order for command execution.
